44. Now to make a sad face, full of pathos
and inner feeling but without
the shedding of tears, as is sometimes the case,
one should slightly raise the eyebrow on the left side,
with the eye half-closed, and underneath,
draw and shorten the crease running
from the nose to the cheek;
thus should one depict a melancholy being.
left-middleHow one should depict inner sadness with the outer movements of the body

45. The head should also hang, turned to one side;
the cheek raised to the aforementioned eye
should pull that side of the mouth open,
one hand on the heart should press the bosom,
and the other should press upon its own shoulder,
with the inside part turned outward,
placed as if to grasp or protect something:
to effectively execute [the depiction of] an oppressed soul.

46. The hands on the heart, lying crosswise,
the head pressed against the shoulder,
yes, thus all the bodyâ€™s citizens join forces,
as the red clouds dampen the fields
of white cheeks with warm rain;
the hands clasped together with fingers interlaced,
and contrary to this, like East and West,
the despondent face should look up toward the other side.

47. Sometimes, to press or wipe crying eyes,
there will be a hand or cloth,
and the hand, supported by the elbow,
should help to keep in place
the head, burdened with doleful moisture.
Yes, all the limbs should almost be
lying asleep or hanging,
as if dead, or fully in the grasp of sickness.

48. For like the dead, the sick, or the old,
the afflicted must often collapse,
his sinking limbs must give way.
Also (to repeat the Poet)
death, sickness, old age and affliction
should dwell together as companions at the portal
of Hell, where they may harmonize well
with other such folk, being birds of a feather.
left-middleAffliction, death, and sickness dwelling at the entrance to Hell. Aeneid, Book 6.

49. The ancient Heathens, fearing the power
of sickness, added it their idols.
In Rome there was the Temple of Fever.
One saw an image of a sick person,
painted not to depict an emotion
but in such a manner that Aristides
was offered more praise for it than other works:
left-middleArt also depicts sickness and death.
